metadata.name: ai-guardrails
metadata.description: Pedantic code enforcement for AI-maintained repositories
metadata.philosophy: AI agents need hard stops. No warnings, no suggestions. Everything is an error or it's ignored. Black/white only.

deployment.use_case: Global installation, used across all projects via ai-guardrails-init

target_users.user: Developers using AI coding assistants (Claude Code, GitHub Copilot, etc.)
Teams wanting strict enforcement of code standards
Projects requiring pedantic type checking and documentation

typical_workflow.step: 2. Run ai-guardrails-init in any project (auto-detects language)
4. All commits blocked until ALL checks pass (no warnings)

compatibility.versioning: Version bumps indicate breaking changes, users update configs when upgrading
compatibility.python_versions: 3.10+ only (can use modern type syntax, match statements, etc.)
compatibility.config_stability: Configs managed centrally in ai-guardrails repo, not per-project customization

component.name: ai-guardrails-init
component.purpose: Copy pedantic configs to target project based on detected language(s)

behavior.requirement: Auto-detect project language(s) by scanning for language-specific files
Support explicit --type flag to override detection
Fail fast with clear error messages if detection fails or conflicts exist

component.name: ai-hooks-init
component.purpose: Set up git hooks for the project

behavior.requirement: Copy hook scripts from lib/hooks/ to .git/hooks/
Optionally install pre-commit config and run pre-commit install
Fail if not in a git repository

component.name: ai-review-tasks
component.purpose: Extract UNRESOLVED CodeRabbit review comments as actionable tasks

behavior.requirement: Fetch PR review threads via GitHub GraphQL API
Fetch PR review bodies via gh pr view --json reviews
Filter: author = coderabbitai AND isResolved = false
Support --pr NUMBER to specify PR (default: current branch PR)
Exit with status 0 on success, non-zero on error

component.integration: CLI tool only, not imported as library

data_flow.step: 1. Fetch review threads via GraphQL (inline comments)
2. Fetch review bodies via gh pr view (üßπ, ‚ö†Ô∏è sections)
5. Pipe to coderabbit_parser.py for unified parsing

component.name: coderabbit_parser.py
component.purpose: Parse CodeRabbit feedback from dual sources into structured tasks
component.critical_design_note:
THIS PARSER PROCESSES TWO SOURCES OF CODERABBIT FEEDBACK:
1. Review thread comments (GraphQL reviewThreads) - Inline comments on specific code lines - Filtered by isResolved=false - Source: TaskSource.THREAD
2. Review body summaries (gh pr view --json reviews) - üßπ Nitpick comments - suggestions (Source: TaskSource.NITPICK) - ‚ö†Ô∏è Outside diff range comments - minor issues (Source: TaskSource.OUTSIDE_DIFF)
Both sources are parsed, merged, and deduplicated. Thread comments take priority over body summaries for duplicates.

source_1.name: threads

comment_body_parsing.description: Each CodeRabbit comment body has a consistent structure

title_extraction.pattern: **Title text** on its own line (after severity line)

ai_prompt_extraction.description: CodeRabbit includes AI-ready prompts in details blocks
ai_prompt_extraction.requirement: Extract full prompt text preserving newlines
This becomes the primary "message" field for the task

description_extraction.description: Text between title and any details blocks
description_extraction.requirement: Strip HTML tags and markdown artifacts

output_schema.requirement: Output must be valid JSON with stable schema
Schema version tracked in output for future compatibility

summary.field: Map of file path to task count

type_checking.requirement: mypy --strict must pass with zero errors
All functions must have complete type annotations
No use of typing.Any (except when truly unavoidable)
Use modern syntax: X | None, not Optional[X]
from __future__ import annotations required at top of file

documentation.requirement: Type hints serve as primary documentation
Docstrings required for public functions/classes (Google style)
Clear variable names preferred over excessive comments
Complex logic must have explanatory comments

error_handling.requirement: Fail fast with clear, actionable error messages
No graceful degradation - exit immediately on errors
Validate inputs at boundaries (CLI, file I/O)
Use custom exception types for different error categories
Never catch broad exceptions (no bare except:)

testing.requirement: Unit tests required for all functions
Integration tests required using real PR data samples
Type checking via mypy is NOT sufficient, explicit tests required

dual_source_design.note: Parser now processes BOTH thread comments AND review body sections

‚ö†Ô∏è Outside diff range comments from review body

dual_source_design.deduplication: Thread comments take priority; key=(file, line_start, title)

code_quality.requirement: Complexity limits: cyclomatic 10, args 5, statements 30, nesting 3
Pathlib required for file paths (no os.path)
Modern syntax enforced (no typing.Optional, use X | None)
Google-style docstrings mandatory for public API
Prefer dataclasses over dicts for structured data

component.name: configs
component.philosophy: Zero escape routes for AI agents - all rules are errors, not warnings

requirements.requirement: from __future__ import annotations required in every file
Modern syntax enforced (no typing.Optional, use X | None)
Complexity limits: 10 cyclomatic, 5 args, 30 statements, 3 nested blocks
No auto-fix (fix = false) - AI must understand errors, not auto-correct
Imports grouped by std/external/crate (NOT "create" - typo fix required)

component.name: pre-commit-hooks
component.philosophy: Fail fast on errors, run 40+ checks in priority order

hook.name: semgrep
hook.requirement: Use --config auto OR pin to specific ruleset (p/default, p/owasp-top-ten)
Document if auto is intentional for staying current

hook.name: pip-audit
hook.requirement: Cannot rely on hook environment only

hook.name: conventional-pre-commit
hook.requirement: Allowed types: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, perf, test, build, ci, chore
Update to latest version (v4.3.0 or newer)

hook.name: codespell
hook.purpose: Typo detection in code and filenames
hook.requirement: Report-only mode aligns with fix = false policy
Update to latest version (v2.4.1 or newer)

component.name: dead-code-detection
component.philosophy: Two complementary approaches catch different types of dead code

tool.name: vulture
tool.purpose: Find unused functions, variables, imports, classes without executing code

strengths.item: Catches "this function is never called anywhere"

limitations.item: False positives with dynamic Python (getattr, **kwargs, plugins)

tool.name: coverage
tool.purpose: Track which lines/branches execute during tests

strengths.item: No false positives - if it ran, it ran

limitations.item: Requires tests to trigger code paths
Too slow for pre-commit (runs full test suite)

usage_guidance.guideline: vulture runs in pre-commit (fast, every commit)
coverage runs in CI (slower, every push/PR)
Use both together for comprehensive dead code detection
vulture finds "never referenced", coverage finds "never executed"

Integration tests required with real data samples
pytest with --strict-markers and --strict-config

Type hints serve as primary documentation
Google-style docstrings for public API

API reference generated from docstrings
Clear variable names over excessive comments
